summary: An email from Matt McDonald, Managing Editor of The Spectator US, to then-U.S. Attorney Geoffrey Berman, requesting comment on a story about Prince Andrew's legal team's claims regarding their cooperation with the Southern District of New York's investigation into Jeffrey Epstein. The story alleges Berman mischaracterized the Duke's lack of cooperation.

persons.name: Matt McDonald
persons.context: Author of the email requesting comment from Geoffrey Berman on a story about Prince Andrew's correspondence with the SDNY.

persons.name: Geoffrey Berman
persons.role: U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York (USANYS)
persons.context: Recipient of the email; accused in the story of misleading the media about Prince Andrew's cooperation and breaching DOJ rules in his public statements.

persons.name: Dominic Green
persons.context: Writer of the story about Prince Andrew's correspondence with the SDNY, excerpts of which are quoted in the email.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.role: Duke of York, Witness/Subject of Investigation
persons.context: Central subject of the story; his legal team claims full cooperation with the SDNY investigation and that Berman's public statements were misleading.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned in relation to his crimes and death, and as the reason the SDNY sought Prince Andrew as a witness.

connections.description: Berman, as U.S. Attorney, publicly denounced Andrew's lack of cooperation, while Andrew's legal team claims they were negotiating in good faith with Berman's office.
The SDNY investigation into Epstein led them to seek Andrew as a witness, and Berman implied Andrew may have aided Epstein's crimes.
McDonald, as a journalist, is seeking comment from Berman on a story critical of his actions.

events.title: Berman's Public Statement at Epstein Townhouse
events.description: U.S. Attorney Geoffrey Berman denounced Prince Andrew from the steps of Jeffrey Epstein's Manhattan townhouse, claiming a 'wall of silence' and 'zero co-operation' from Andrew.

events.title: BBC Broadcast of Accusations
events.description: The BBC broadcast accusations related to the Epstein case in November 2019, after which the DOJ approached Prince Andrew.

events.title: Andrew's Legal Team Proposes Witness Statement Plan
events.description: In early January 2020, Prince Andrew's new legal team suggested drafting a proposal for how he would deliver his witness statement, which the DOJ reportedly accepted.

keyFacts: Prince Andrew's legal team claims to have 'dozens of email exchanges' proving full cooperation with the SDNY, contradicting U.S. Attorney Geoffrey Berman's public statements.
The DOJ first approached Prince Andrew as a witness only after Epstein's death in August 2019 and a BBC broadcast in November 2019, not as a suspect.
Berman's January 2020 statement implying Andrew aided Epstein's crimes is characterized by Andrew's source as an 'overt breach' of DOJ rules for engaging witnesses.
Andrew's legal team chose not to release private emails that would prove they were negotiating in good faith with the SDNY.
